title.narrative: Enhanced Religious Freedom Protection at the Local Level in Indonesia

description.narrative: The Asia Foundation (the Foundation) was awarded USD1,173,830 (equivalent to € 1,000,000) by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN) to implement a three-year project on Enhancing Religious Freedom Protection and Human Rights at the Local Level in Indonesia. The Cooperative Agreement (award) was signed by EKN’s Minister Plenipotentiary and Deputy Head of Missions, and counter-signed by the Foundation’s Country Representative, Indonesia on November 15, 2018. The Award period is from November 15, 2018 to November 14, 2021.

The Foundation will work at the national and local level. At the national level, the project will work with Komnas HAM and The Ministry of Education and Culture. At the local level, the project will be implemented at three project's objectives in four out of ten least tolerant cities based on Setara Institute Assessment Report in 2017. They include Bogor City (West Java), Kulonprogo District (Jogjakarta), Bukit Tinggi City (West Sumatera), and Banjarmasin (South Kalimantan). Apart from the Setara Institute Report, the Foundation's criteria for these target areas include places where the Foundation and its proposed partners have relationship with relevant government or local civil society actors. Specifically, in Bukit Tinggi City, out of the three objectives identified in the project's Theory of Change, the project will only target the objective on promoting more active and consolidated civil society networks.

The Program is intended to be a flexible mechanism with overall development goal “Enhanced Religious Freedom Protection at the Local Level in Indonesia.” This project envisages improvement through three indicators that are commonly used to measure a state of religious freedom in democratic society. They include state policy that restrict freedom of religion and beliefs, government actions that restrict freedom including favoritism toward certain religion and social regulation or social hostilities. To accomplish its objectives, this project proposes to improve the capacity of the national government, local government, and civil society institutions and facilitate the interaction and collaboration among them in promoting freedom of religion. The project will contribute to the EKN’s Human Rights Fund Grant Policy Framework 2017-2020 to promote and protect human rights particularly under the theme of freedom of religion with the overall objective of ‘promoting every individual's freedom to express their identity, as informed by religious or other beliefs.’
